update.description:
This is a graft from the spielman fork, which I've done my best to isolate from other changes I'll make a separate pull request for.

This change introduces a 'default baudrate' setting for the Novatech. Basically, this is the baud rate you expect the Novatech to be in when you power it on, and when you don't have one of the models where you can change a jumper to make them always at the fastest speed.
If you use this setting, the novatech will be told at startup to switch from its default baudrate to the one BLACS will actually talk to it with, and then the serial connection restarted with the new baudrate. Then at shutdown, the novatech is set back to its default baudrate, which is also nice if you don't want to confuse other software that needs to talk to the novatech and has expectations about its baudrate.
update.title: Novatech default baudrate

content.raw:
Thanks David, your method \(now included in this PR\) worked an absolute treat.

Basically the remaining issue with this pull request prior to including your method was that restarting a tab in BLACS does _not_ run shutdown code for that tab, even if the tab is not in an error state. Therefore the ‘default baud rate’ was not being restored upon tab restart, and so the initialisation code could not talk to the device. The only way around this previously was to power cycle the device to restore its default baud rate, but with your trick the startup code can now work with the device in either case. It seems to be working excellently.
content.html:
Thanks David, your method (now included in this PR) worked an absolute treat.

Basically the remaining issue with this pull request prior to including your method was that restarting a tab in BLACS does not run shutdown code for that tab, even if the tab is not in an error state. Therefore the ‘default baud rate’ was not being restored upon tab restart, and so the initialisation code could not talk to the device. The only way around this previously was to power cycle the device to restore its default baud rate, but with your trick the startup code can now work with the device in either case. It seems to be working excellently.

content.raw: Ah, fantastic. I’ll just look at the successor then. Thanks!
content.html: Ah, fantastic. I’ll just look at the successor then. Thanks!

content.raw:
Totally fine by me! Getting the baud rate was definitely annoying since the only way to know what the current baud rate is is to just try them all and see which one gives a sensible response.

We’ve been using this code without issue for almost a year now. The linked code appears to be up to date with all my bugfixes on that feature, but I won’t guarantee it since I recently ported everything over to the arbitrary subfolder architecture so code diffs are a little harder to track \(ie the linked file no longer exists in the mainline\). The spiritual successor is now [here](https://bitbucket.org/dihm/naqslab_devices/src/default/NovaTechDDS/blacs_worker.py).
content.html:
Totally fine by me! Getting the baud rate was definitely annoying since the only way to know what the current baud rate is is to just try them all and see which one gives a sensible response.

We’ve been using this code without issue for almost a year now. The linked code appears to be up to date with all my bugfixes on that feature, but I won’t guarantee it since I recently ported everything over to the arbitrary subfolder architecture so code diffs are a little harder to track (ie the linked file no longer exists in the mainline). The spiritual successor is now here.

content.raw:
Hi David,

I started testing this pull request’s code today and got tripped up a bit, something about it is unreliable, even though I had though that all the kinks were worked out. I may steal your code to try and make talking to the device more robust, if that’s OK!
content.html:
Hi David,

I started testing this pull request’s code today and got tripped up a bit, something about it is unreliable, even though I had though that all the kinks were worked out. I may steal your code to try and make talking to the device more robust, if that’s OK!

content.raw: If you are interested I've worked out a general way to configure any baud rate even when the current baud rate is unknown for our Novatech 409Bs. The code is [here](https://bitbucket.org/dihm/naqslab_devices/src/f752216883e46e2392437d1c795aafa29135a7d1/NovaTechDDS409B_AC.py?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#NovaTechDDS409B_AC.py-265) in the worker init\(\) method. We've been using it for a while and it seems robust.
content.html: If you are interested I've worked out a general way to configure any baud rate even when the current baud rate is unknown for our Novatech 409Bs. The code is here in the worker init() method. We've been using it for a while and it seems robust.

content.raw:
note that some changes are due to me since I did manual merging with hg graft - I changed the strings to be explicitly bytestrings to be friendlier to the upcoming Python 3 changes, I changed the way of indicating "no default baud rate" to `None` instead of 0, and I added backward compatibility about the BLACS connection.

Regarding the BLACS connection: in 2014 I changed it to be a `COM_port,baudrate` tuple, and now that there are more settings everything is in the connection table properties and we could remove the baudrate from the BLACS_connection. In fact, in this pull request the com port is in connection table properties too, and the backward compatibility is only even looking at BLACS_connection if it doesn't get everything it needs from the connection table properties. (but BLACS won't make a tab unless the BLACS connection is a nonempty string)
content.html:
note that some changes are due to me since I did manual merging with hg graft - I changed the strings to be explicitly bytestrings to be friendlier to the upcoming Python 3 changes, I changed the way of indicating "no default baud rate" to None instead of 0, and I added backward compatibility about the BLACS connection.

Regarding the BLACS connection: in 2014 I changed it to be a COM_port,baudrate tuple, and now that there are more settings everything is in the connection table properties and we could remove the baudrate from the BLACS_connection. In fact, in this pull request the com port is in connection table properties too, and the backward compatibility is only even looking at BLACS_connection if it doesn't get everything it needs from the connection table properties. (but BLACS won't make a tab unless the BLACS connection is a nonempty string)
